text: Gijón (Asturian: Xixón) is a city in the autonomous community of Asturias in Spain. It is located on the Bay of Biscay, about north of Oviedo. Gijón has a population of 275,274 inhabitants, more than any other city in Asturias. == History == For most of its history Gijón was just a small town and seaport.Southern Europe: International Dictionary of Historic Places, Volume 3, eds. Trudy Ring; Noelle Watson; Paul Schellinger (Oxford; New York: Routledge, 2010), p. 284 After the conquest of the Asturias in the 3rd century BC by the Romans they called the site Gigia. in 714 a garrison was established by the Moors. From here they attacked the Asturias but failed in the attempt. After the Moors left, Gijón was ruled by Asturian kings. In the 10th century the Asturias became part of the Kingdom of León. In the 16th century the harbor was improved under Philip II of Spain. Some of the ships of the Spanish Armada took shelter at Gijón's port in a violent storm. They were on their way to attack Britain in 1588.James McDermott, Martin Frobisher: Elizabethan Privateer (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001), p. 344 After the epic battle, a few of the remaining ships limped back to Gijón. During the last half of the 19th century a railroad was built to Gijón to ship Asturian coal to other parts of Spain. This was the start of Gijón becoming a large industrial center. During the Spanish Civil War part of Gijón was destroyed.Dana Facaros; Michael Pauls, Northern Spain (London: Cadogan Guides, 2008), p. 225 == Modern Gijón == Gijón is famous for its beaches. Every November the Gijón International Film Festival is held. The main stage is the Jovellanos Theatre, although other cinemas and cultural centres are also used. == References == == Other websites == * Gijón International Film Festival * GIJÓN Category:Cities in Asturias Category:Municipalities in Asturias Category:5th-century BC establishments
